title: Can I listen to music without an internet connection? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, this is impossible. Even though modern technology allows us to connect any computer to any server on the other side of the planet, using undersea cables that are hundreds of miles long, connecting continents across oceans, somehow nobody has figured out how to play mp3 files without an internet connection yet. Currently, however, a team of experts is working on the problem in an unprecedented attempt to solve one of our biggest problems to date. It has been given the status of “Galactic Problem”, similar to the mathematical “Millenium Problems”, but of a much larger scale. The so-called “phonographs” that came up in the late 19th century are considered a huge scam that managed to fool the whole world, making our generation shake our heads to this day. CD’s were actually an experiment administered by the NSA that, according to certain sources, was supposed to damage our brains so that everyone would think they were listening to music. so if anyone tells you that they’re listening to music without an internet connection, tell them to grow up and educate themselves. [in cased you haven’t realised, of course you can listen to music without an internet connection, you just need mp3/wav/etc. files on your computer/phone, a vinyl disk and a phonograph, or a CD and a CD player]

Yes you can. And there are many, many ways to do so: Listening to Radio Pros:  possible 	on a great variety of devicesNo Internet RequiredCons: 	You 	need to have a Radio station near you, and you can't decide freely 	what to listen (except changing Radio stations) On Smartphones/Laptops/PCs and other Devices with a Data storage Pros:  depended on the storage medium you almost have unlimited Music running time	You 	can freely decide what to listen (if you have downloaded it once)You 	can record own Music tracks (from Analog Media for example)	Indie 	Titles are easy available (means, not Mainstream tracks, and also 	from Hobbyists sharing their music on the Internet)Cons: You 	mostly need once in a while a connection to the „outer World“ 	for downloading media You 	need to organize your Music library, to have fast access to the 	songs you like Cassette-Player (also Walkman)/Vinyl Pros: Runs 	entirely analog, so you don't have to worry about crashes and startup 	times of the device (tap n play)	Lots 	of older Music and also sometimes brand new stuff available	All 	you need is Power to run it, absolutely no Internet connection 	required	You 	also can record own Songs to a tape (sadly not to a Vinyl)	If 	you have time, you can create your own Mix tape, with your favorite 	Music	Good 	for on the Run with an WalkmanCons: You 	can skip a Song, but due to its linear nature, you need to wait until the song is past while fast forwardingIt 	needs more space than Digital Media	For 	Walkman you need to buy batterys	Vinyls 	are needing carefully handling CD-Player/CD-Walkman Pros: Lots 	of Music available, older as also new one	You 	can burn your own CDs with your Favorites on it	You 	can easily hike it up with an HIFI-DeviceCons: Needs 	a bit more space than Digital Media on a HDD/SD Card for example	CDs 	must be protected from scratches	They 	are getting „Outdated“ That's it from my Point of View, i hope i answered your Question, as you can see there are lots of different ways to listen to music, without connecting to the Internet (for example when you have a limited Data Volume Contract) A note to your Question:Because its "only" a Can I listen to music without an internet connection? I only can guess, what devices you have, or what kind of solution you thought of. So i'm just giving a few possibility's for listening to music on the Go and stationary without Internet access or with one time Internet access. If you have any further Questions, just ask, i will try to answer them. Greetings Kalabint/Benjamin

There are still physical media, you know? So, if you want to listen to music without using the internet, get a CD… or a Vinyl if you want to go the hipster route… And if all else fails, there is still radio. I mean, sure, I also don’t really see the appeal of using physical media these days, but, they are an option if you are without internet. Hell, you might even get interested in bygone media and have some fun with older tech, (re)live the days people associated pencils with their stereo, or go even further back and get open reel to reel to play after failing five times to get the tape threaded into the playback machine correctly. Or basically: are you really that dependent on the internet for your music? If yes, you might want to overthink stuff.

Sure! I have hundreds of CDs and a CD player. I have a dozen cassette tapes and a cassette tape player. I have a stack of vinyl records and a record player. I have AM, FM, and XM radio tuners. None of these require internet. I also have several music instruments in my house. They do not require internet. The other day I was at a festival and a band was playing. They were not connected to the internet. I have family access to Google Play Music and YouTube Red. My daughter downloads music to listen to offline because I limit her data.

Sure! I have hundreds of CDs and a CD player. I have a dozen cassette tapes and a cassette tape player. I have a stack of vinyl records and a record player. I have AM, FM, and XM radio tuners. None of these require internet. If you want to use is: Youtube Cache App I also have several music instruments in my house. They do not require internet. The other day I was at a festival and a band was playing. They were not connected to the internet.  I have family access to Google Play Music and YouTube Red. My daughter downloads music to listen to offline because I limit her data.

There are still radio stations on the air. Listening to their broadcasts is free. CDs are a reliable option, and used ones can be had at low cost. Be sure to inspect used CDs for scratches before buying them. Records are another option that can be very inexpensive when purchased second-hand. However, records are more fragile than CDs. Records that have been played on poor quality/badly adjusted turntables, with worn-out needles, or simply too many times can have damage that is invisible but that will make them sound awful. Playing shellac 78 RPM records requires a special needle different from those designed for vinyl records. There are several types of magnetic tape media: Compact Cassettes, open reel, 8-track, and Pocket Rockers. All of these can be found on the used market, although the Pocket Rockers were somewhat of a novelty item with a very limited selection of titles.

Besides the many suggestions already offered in the previous answers — I would highly recommend going to live music performances near you. Go and actually see music being made by people, instruments and devices right in front of your very eyes. Attend shows and gigs that feature local acts, symphonic concerts, group shows and open mikes of any and all genres. Watching the music being crafted and played right in front of you is a miraculous multi-sensoral phenomena that can touch you through vibration, emotionality, mood, atmosphere, delivery. I also highly encourage going to see local musicians and ensembles in more intimate and smaller venues — maybe even attend a house party or 2 where music is being showcased by the talent in your city, town or neighborhood. These contexts are where the direct human connection between performer, the music and a listener establishes the deepest resonance with what music is all about.

I might ask YOU: how do you listen to music WITH any kind of Internet? Physical CDs, tapes, LPs, 45 or 78 rpm singles, Edison Cylinders on real machines that played them. Better yet, learn to play an instrument. As Tom Petty opinined, ditch your computer, pick up a guitar. Or better yet, another instrument—since there are so many guitarists, playing something else might get you more chances to play with others.

As Jorge Quintas said... Music was invented before internet and electronic gadgets... If you want to hear music w/o internet.. 1. Leave all gadgets2. Take a walk outside alone to a pleasant area.3. Hear the birds sing.4. Hear the winds blow.5. Hear the tree talk.Etc. All just happens.. Music is not what you just hear. Its what you take. Everything us music.☺

Yes, you can.Download the "Spotify" player with a correct user name and password. When you have a WiFi connection, you can easily put your favorite songs to offline modus and listen to them when you're not connected to internet. You can also download your favorite music On iTunes, and play it with your iPhone/iPod or mp3 player.  @thomasbergetwit

/grin… The old-fashioned way. We used to call it “radio”.  AM broadcasting - Wikipedia We also had these strange physical things that actually had music on them. Tapes, CD’s, even these really huge frisbee-looking plastic things called “records”. You had to have a machine that played them, too.  records - Google Search
Why would you need internet to listen to music? Music was invented well before internet and people still listened.

Buy the cd and a cd player. There are a lot of used cds on the Amazon marketplace, and cd players are cheap since they're no longer a commodity. If you don't have internet, rip the songs onto someone else's computer and upload them to your phone. Also, you could try to listening to the radio.

Live music Radio Cd Vinyl Make your own In the streaming era there is a very long tail for cds. Prices are low, especially second hand. Choice is huge. There has never been a better time to buy physical music, so go and explore
Yes you can listen to music without a internet connection only if you have a music app already downloaded on your mobile device, if not then no you cannot listen to music without internet connection.
no，you can’t

CD Players and Walkmans! They both can be found pretty cheap now that mobile devices and the digital world rule the music industry. Also, CD’s can be found cheap at garage sales or at thrift stores. They can also be found full price at stores like Wal-Mart.
Yes you can
Yes
